title: What is the Research on the Feeling of Being Stared at and its Connection to Facial Expressions and Hypnosis?
first_phrase: The last part of the text delves into the study of facial expressions and their role in human communication. It cites the work of Paul Ekman, Silvan Tomkins, and Wallace Friesen who developed the "Facial Affect Scoring Technique" to analyze facial expressions. Other important names mentioned are ethologist Desmond Morris and Volgyesi, who wrote about animal and human hypnosis. The text also discusses the physiological aspects related to the gaze and how it can affect reptiles and humans. Overall, the text presents a multidisciplinary approach to understanding the complex phenomena of nonverbal communication.

last_phrase: In conclusion, whether ancient myths or modern research, there is evidence that the gaze of a snake, or any animal, can have a powerful effect on humans and other creatures. While some may attempt to use this effect for hypnosis or other purposes, it's important to understand and respect the potential dangers of manipulating this natural phenomenon.
